The above post misrepresents the role played by the Federal Reserve. 

Under the existing system banks *are* free to offer loans at whichever rate of interest they choose based on the supply of reserves and the demand for loans. The central bank simply offers loans to private banks at a lower rate than they offer loans to the general public. This means if a bank loans out deposits and depositors want their money back before the loan repayments are due, the bank can borrow the cash from the central bank. Making it safer for banks to loan out money allows them to supply more loans.

The effect of the central bank lowering the interest rates is therefore indirect: being able to borrow money cheaply from the Fed means banks can safely make loans at lower rates *if they think they will profit from doing so.*

Austrian economists argue that allowing banks to borrow money cheaply inevitably leads to malinvestment - banks lending money that will never be repaid. Most economists think this *does not* adequately explain bad lending practices. Most agree low interest rates can *sometimes* be a bad idea where they encourage lending that leads to inflationary increases in spending
